item.title: The 12 Best Games On The Nintendo Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
The Switch 2 is quickly approaching its one-year anniversary. Nine months in, how is the game library on Nintendo‚Äôs new flagship console shaping up? Quite well. What it lacks in the big exclusives we saw during the first year of its predecessor, it‚Äôs making up for with great versions of some of the best big-budget games around, as well as perfectly timed sequels from storied indie franchises. If you‚Äôre thinking of buying a Switch 2 or already have one, here are the 12 best games to check out on Nintendo‚Äôs latest handheld hybrid.

Final Fantasy VII Remake Intergrade

One of the best RPGs ever got one of the best remakes ever and the whole thing is finally on Switch 2. Final Fantasy VII Remake Intergrade preserves the irresistible mix of grim and goofy that seared the original into so many people‚Äôs brains while elevating its story and gameplay to new heights with beautiful cinematic setpieces and solid real-time hybrid action combat. Everything from the original‚Äôs incredible soundtrack to its story‚Äôs most unforgettable moments are reimagined and stretched out in service of a journey that feels both epic and compact. The Switch 2 port offers all of that with even fewer compromises than expected, making Final Fantasy VII Remake Intergrade the platform‚Äôs biggest and more rewarding big-budget RPG adventure yet. ‚Äî Ethan Gach

A good match for: brooding eco-terrorists who love the city in Blade Runner and collecting crystals.
Not a good match for: players who hate when games pause the action for lots of cutscenes.

Kirby Air Riders

Kirby Air Riders is a tricked-out hotrod that‚Äôs as fun to tinker with as it is to drive. It‚Äôs overflowing with systems, mechanics, and stylish details, all packaged into fun and easy-to-manage bite-size morsels. What Smash Bros. is to fighting games, Air Riders is to racing games. It‚Äôs first and foremost a party game you‚Äôre meant to hang out and mess around in. Competition and heated rivalries are secondary to frenetic moment-to-moment action and a quintessentially satisfying game feel that makes every turn, boost, and attack so good, you forget that underneath all the ostentatious ornamentation there‚Äôs not a ton of depth. Who cares? Splashing in puddles can be just as fun as surfing over waves. ‚Äî Ethan Gach

A good match for: people who wish go-karting felt more like smashing gumball machines.
Not a good match for: anyone who enjoys being anywhere near an actual race track.

Star Wars Outlaws

Ubisoft‚Äôs Star Wars scoundrel sim Outlaws, like so many of the company‚Äôs big open-world games, feels a bit awkward and unrefined in spots. Enemy behavior can be too simplistic, and some of your tricks for manipulating them can make you feel more like a Jedi than a smuggler. But, in the immortal words of Han Solo, ‚Äúshe‚Äôs got it where it counts.‚Äù Outlaws puts you in the world of Star Wars like few games have, letting you soak up the atmosphere of backwater cantinas and more bustling city joints, claim victory at sabacc tables far and wide against some of the steeliest gamblers in the Outer Rim, and rise up the ranks of the criminal underworld as you assemble a crew for the one big job that‚Äôs gonna set you up for life. It‚Äôs also one of the most impressive games on Switch 2, where a masterful port keeps it looking great and running smooth with few visible compromises. ‚Äî Carolyn Petit

A good match for: people who want to soak in the vibes of every bar and cantina from Tatooine to Toshara.Not a good match for: people seeking Hitman or Metal Gear-level stealth gameplay.

Hades 2

Hades 2 feels less like a sequel than a standalone expansion. It will never escape the shadow of the first game. But it is more Hades, a roguelike action-RPG that‚Äôs still setting the bar in each of those genres. It doesn‚Äôt feel as warm and personal and as accessible as the original, but it‚Äôs expertly balanced, beautifully presented, and still so hard to put down. ‚Äî Ethan Gach

A good match for: fans of Greek mythology who think it needs more buildcrafting.
Not a good match for: folks who hate playing the same great levels over and over again.

Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A

After a year or two, every Pok√©mon game inevitably gets to a point where the community looks back fondly on it. So while there are plenty of folks still in the rage phase with this one, I‚Äôm just gonna forgo the waiting period and say that Pok√©mon Legends: Z-A is one of the best, boldest games in the long-running monster-taming series. The single-city setting allows you to hang out with one of the series‚Äô best casts for far longer than any of previous games have, and its real-time battle system is full of new nuances and strategies you won‚Äôt find in your average turn-based Pok√©mon game. After two games, we know the Legends subseries has become Game Freak‚Äôs place to experiment, so it‚Äôs entirely possible the next one won‚Äôt look or play anything like Z-A, but it would be nice if these action systems made their way to more games. They‚Äôre too good to toss aside after just one entry. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

A Good Match For: people who want a Pok√©mon experience that doesn‚Äôt feel like more of the same.Not A Good Match For: people who want windows to be lovingly rendered.

Hollow Knight: Silksong

There are no half-measures in Hollow Knight: Silksong. Exploration is carefully crafted and uncompromisingly exacting. Boss fights will force you to learn and improve before unblocking your path. The music is excellent, the little sound effects amazing, and every part of Silksong‚Äòs gothic underground labyrinth is full of rich veins of lore and character to mine. It‚Äôs a game that thrives in the tension between limitation and mastery and never fails to reward those who soldier on no matter how often their effort and ambition is momentarily shunted.  ‚Äî Ethan Gach

A good match for: Metroidvania nerds who love exploring dangerous tunnels.
Not a good match for: Anyone who hates dying in Soulslikes.

Cyberpunk 2077 

CD Projekt Red‚Äôs open-world RPG is one of the most impressive technical showcases for the Switch 2 thus far. Cyberpunk 2077 once broke PlayStation 4s and Xbox Ones across the globe, but it runs well on Nintendo‚Äôs system. Driving around Night City is still a dream, and the Switch 2‚Äôs optional mouse controls are pretty intuitive in the game‚Äôs shooting segments. There are certainly better ways to play Cyberpunk 2077, but seeing it running on a Switch 2 is a reminder that while the system might seem like a pretty lowkey upgrade from the original, playing console-quality games on the go is still a novel experience eight years later. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

A good match for: story-driven RPG fans.
Not a good match for: people with a weak stomach for some tough subject matter.

The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom

It‚Äôs no surprise that the two best games on the original Switch are vastly improved in their Switch 2 incarnations. Breath of the Wild and Tears of the Kingdom run at a smooth 60fps on the Switch 2, and if seeing these games running on a device that doesn‚Äôt feel like it‚Äôs struggling to keep them afloat isn‚Äôt enough, the Switch 2 editions come with new content thanks to the Zelda Notes app that adds new challenges and lore to two already dense games. If you played them before, they‚Äôre worth revisiting. If you never touched Link‚Äôs open-world adventures, they‚Äôre even more essential on the Switch 2. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

A good match for: people who want peak.
Not a good match for: people who get overwhelmed with dense systems.

Mario Kart World

Nintendo‚Äôs biggest launch title for the Switch 2 is still arguably the best game the system has to offer. Mario Kart World is a sublime addition to the kart racer series‚Äô long line of quality party game staples. Though it‚Äôs not without its frustrations, World presents the chaotic, rollicking fun of throwing a blue shell down a track or barreling through your enemies as a Bullet Bill at its best. The open world is kind of empty, but it‚Äôs a fun playground to practice all the cool stunts you can do now, like riding on the wall and grinding on rails. Mario Kart World is all about giving you the freedom to race how you want, and that means giving you more tools, more players on the track at once, and more bothersome items to chuck at your foes. This is only the beginning, and Nintendo will likely be updating the game for years to come. Mario Kart World will undoubtedly be a staple of the Switch 2‚Äôs lifetime. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

A good match for: everyone, really.
Not a good match for: anyone looking for something chill.

Split Fiction

Hazelight‚Äôs co-op platformer Split Fiction doesn‚Äôt feel built for the Switch 2. Its split-screen format makes it a pain to play in tabletop mode, so it‚Äôs really best played on a TV like you would on PS5 or Xbox. But once you‚Äôve got it running on a big screen, the game is still a hoot. Though its cheesy writing leaves much to be desired, as a cooperative platformer with a ton of mechanical and environmental variety, it‚Äôs easily the best in Hazelight‚Äôs long line of co-op games. That final level still whips ass, too. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

A good match for: someone with a friend to play with.
Not a good match for: someone who doesn‚Äôt have a friend to play with.

Street Fighter 6

Fighting games were always going to be one of the biggest tests of the Switch 2‚Äôs technical capabilities, and Capcom thankfully managed to bring one of the best genre entries in recent years to the system without much compromise in Street Fighter 6. Some of its Switch 2 features, like amiibo support and motion controls with the Joy-Cons, feel like cute nods to the system‚Äôs original features rather than something that fundamentally changes the game, so you‚Äôll most likely go right back to standard play before long. Once you do, though, you‚Äôll find a really great version of an already stellar game running at a smooth 60fps. Sure, it‚Äôs probably not going to be the version people are playing at EVO, but it‚Äôs more than good enough to break out at the function and play with friends. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

A good match for: the fighting game sickos.
Not a good match for: people who don‚Äôt like to memorize combos.

Donkey Kong Bananza

Donkey Kong and Pauline‚Äôs latest adventure is one of the Switch 2‚Äôs most impressive technical achievements. Its breakable environments are so malleable that they‚Äôre a bit of a distraction, but its tight platforming, creative problem-solving, and booming personality make it one of the most joyful games on the Switch 2 right now. Is it the cultural moment the system needed to bring people in out of the gate? Maybe not. But it‚Äôs still an absolute delight on its own terms. ‚Äî Kenneth Shepard

A good match for: people who wanted King Kong to have a happier ending.
Not a good match for: people who can‚Äôt move on without finding every collectable in a level.

item.title: Counter-Strike Pros Keep Switching To This New Mouse That Lets Them Shoot Even Faster
item.content:encoded:
Usually, pro esports players are hesitant to change up their peripherals, especially before a big tournament. Getting comfortable with a new keyboard or mouse can be especially daunting when, y‚Äôknow, your entire job is on the line. But a new mouse is making waves in a Counter-Strike 2 tournament as players try to get any edge they can in the team-based shooter. 

Logitech only just released the X2 Superstrike and the new $180 gaming mouse is already becoming a fast favorite for competitive Counter-Strike 2 players. As pointed out by IGN, 13 of the ongoing PGL Cluj-Napoca tournament‚Äôs remaining 50 players have all switched over to the X2 Superstrike. Apparently no one wants to prioritize familiarity over potentially losing out on reaction time. 

Logitech‚Äôs website boasts that the mouse is a ‚Äúbreakthrough in ultra-low click-latency technology.‚Äù It uses something called a Haptic Inductive Trigger System (or HITS) instead of traditional switches to allow users to click with a lot less travel time while receiving customizable haptic feedback. Basically, it saves players even more time from the second they try to fire off a gun in an online multiplayer shooter to the instant the hit registers on the enemy player.

PART 1. Here is my feedback on this mouse. It's a game changer. NO, you won't become good with this NO, but yes, the click response is faster, which I really like, and it's really great and excellent of Logitech to have created this technology. Part 2 below üîΩ https://t.co/RNQIk6L4q3 pic.twitter.com/l6XvScTLUO

‚Äî Polo922 (@Polo922_) February 13, 2026

How much time, exactly? Up to 30 milliseconds. That‚Äôs 20 milliseconds less than the average time it takes a human to blink their eye. The X2 Superstrike effectively gets you a half-blink advantage over the competition if you‚Äôre skilled enough to need it. It‚Äôs probably not beneficial to casual players, but for competitive players, a more responsive mouse that can fire just a few ticks earlier can be a game-changer. 

According to IGN, Logitech apparently sped up the technology‚Äôs development after receiving encouragement from pros who tested it. This isn‚Äôt really a surprise, however, considering the fact that the X2 is basically a fancier spiritual successor to the Superlight 2, which was already a top pick for CS2 pros.

We do know that some (if not all) of these players had access to the mouse in advance. Kscerato already won the MVP award at the Thunderpick World Championships using the mouse back in October. Still, it‚Äôs pretty impressive to see a mouse taking over a competition so quickly, especially considering that a few high-ranking teams like the Mongolz, Team Falcons, and FURIA now have half their players using the mouse.

The X2 Superstrike is obviously a new favorite in the CS2 community, but I‚Äôm personally curious to see if the mouse spreads to other esports. Based on its newfound status as a hot commodity among CS2 pros, I could see it becoming the default gaming mouse in other competitive games like Valorant and League as well‚Äîthat is, if it isn‚Äôt banned.
